content: A new Post Nearby feature allows you to send out messages to those who you’re near at a particular time. When posted, Notes will be sent out as a push notification to the people around you using Highlight and will appear at the top of those individual’s activity feed. New Interest Pages let you see at a glance what other Highlight users might share a particular interest with you. Notes allow you to leave messages about your friends for others who encounter them to read. When you make a post on Highlight, that post can also be shared on Facebook at the same time. Redesigned profile pages will show your last post at the top of the page. Posts can be commented on as well as liked. The activity feed within Highlight has been redesigned in this release to incorporate the new types of content the app now supports. Notes about people you’ve crossed paths with, posts from people nearby, and information about people your friends have highlighted will all now show up in the activity feed. The location-sharing app Highlight is getting its biggest update since its white-hot launch at SXSW in March. Powered by information from your Facebook profile, Highlight lets you know when you're near people you know, as well as people with whom you share mutual friends or interests. Thursday's update adds a number of new features, ranging from the ability to send a group message to people located nearby, to a feature that lets you leave LinkedIn-style recommendations and notes for your friends on the service. If you're already a Highlight user, then the app is going to to feel like a whole new — and improved — experience. The co-founder says he’s heard countless stories from people who have made connections using it since launch. “Every time I meet with someone they say ‘I have this crazy Highlight story to tell you,’” Highlight’s Paul Davison told Mashable in an interview earlier this week. “If someone’s near you reaching out to them isn’t weird,” he said, commenting on approaching someone Highlight notifies you about. For instance, knowing the person sitting next to you at a coffee shop is friends with your sister who lives across the country is cause to strike up a conversation. Highlight points out the connections you have with the world around you, which Davison feels can make the world seem like a smaller place and connects people who might have otherwise never known each other. Let's take a deeper dive in to some of the app's new features. A new Post Nearby feature allows you to send messages to those who you’re near at a particular time. When posted, Notes will be sent out as a push notification to the people around you using Highlight and will appear at the top of those individuals' activity feed. Davison sees the feature as being used for things like asking for an iPhone charger from others at a coffee shop, or asking to share a cab home from a networking event. The possibilities are endless. Posts can be responded to by others on Highlight, and when you move, your note will move along with you. For instance, if you’re on a business trip and ask the masses for bar recommendations while you’re at your hotel, the note will also show up when you decide to hit the bar a few blocks down the road, allowing you to potentially get better suggestions. In this release, Highlight has tweaked the algorithm that produces notifications on the service, which Davison says will create results that are more timely, personalized and interesting. Highlight is also making the notifications you get a little more personal. Just like you might highlight a particular person you find interesting on the service, now you can also highlight particular interests that you care about. So, if you’d love to meet people who love the same bands you do, but could do without meeting people who also enjoy “hugging,” then you can let the app know. New Interest Pages bring together all the people on Highlight who have a particular thing in common with you. For instance, if you’re at a party and want to know if anyone will support putting Lady Gaga on the stereo, you can tap "Lady Gaga" and instantly see who your allies in the room might be. Power users can now fine-tune what notifications they receive with more granular controls in the app’s settings. Much like you can on LinkedIn , Highlight now allows you to leave notes on the profiles of people you know that will be visible to others who visit that person’s profile. For instance, you might write a note on a friend’s page saying “Ask John to tell you what happened on his trip to Hawaii,” if John has a particularly interesting tale to tell. Or you might simply leave a note letting the world know how great John is. You’ll need to be Facebook friends with a person in order to leave a note, and the note can be deleted by both the person who wrote it and the owner of the profile. That way if someone says something you don’t like, you can get rid of it. The activity feed within Highlight has been redesigned in this release to incorporate the new types of content the app now supports. Notes about people you’ve crossed paths with, posts from people nearby, and information about people your friends have highlighted will all now show up in the activity feed. From the feed you can now like and reply to posts. So, if you someone asks for an iPhone charger and you have one you can reply in-line from your Activity feed so everyone else can see. Highlight has always gotten information about your mutual friends and interests from Facebook, and now the app lets you share to Facebook some information about what you do on Highlight. Now when you highlight someone else, write a post, or write a note about someone, you can choose to share that information on your Facebook profile. You can also post a summary – along with pictures – of everyone you’ve encountered in a particular day. Everyone pictured will have to have also enabled the Facebook-sharing feature on their phones. Highlight is now available in French, Italian, German, Spanish, Dutch, Portuguese, Brazilian Portuguese, Chinese, Japanese and Korean. You can download Highlight’s latest update now from the App Store . Check out the gallery above for a look at some of the new features, and let us know what you think of the update in the comments.
title_html: Location-Sharing App Highlight Gets Biggest Update Since Launch

Location-Sharing App Highlight Gets Biggest Update Since Launch

Share
Tweet
What's This?
By Emily Price2012-07-19 09:00:27 UTC

Highlight 1.2

  1. Post Nearby

    A new Post Nearby feature allows you to send out messages to those who you’re near at a particular time. When posted, Notes will be sent out as a push notification to the people around you using Highlight and will appear at the top of those individual’s activity feed.

  2. Interest Pages

    New Interest Pages let you see at a glance what other Highlight users might share a particular interest with you.

  3. Notes

    Notes allow you to leave messages about your friends for others who encounter them to read.

  4. Facebook Sharing

    When you make a post on Highlight, that post can also be shared on Facebook at the same time.

  5. Redesigned Profile Pages

    Redesigned profile pages will show your last post at the top of the page.

  6. Comments and Likes

    Posts can be commented on as well as liked.

  7. Improved Activity Feed

    The activity feed within Highlight has been redesigned in this release to incorporate the new types of content the app now supports. Notes about people you’ve crossed paths with, posts from people nearby, and information about people your friends have highlighted will all now show up in the activity feed.

The location-sharing app Highlight is getting its biggest update since its white-hot launch at SXSW in March.

Powered by information from your Facebook profile, Highlight lets you know when you're near people you know, as well as people with whom you share mutual friends or interests.

Thursday's update adds a number of new features, ranging from the ability to send a group message to people located nearby, to a feature that lets you leave LinkedIn-style recommendations and notes for your friends on the service.

If you're already a Highlight user, then the app is going to to feel like a whole new — and improved — experience.

The co-founder says he’s heard countless stories from people who have made connections using it since launch.

“Every time I meet with someone they say ‘I have this crazy Highlight story to tell you,’” Highlight’s Paul Davison told Mashable in an interview earlier this week. “If someone’s near you reaching out to them isn’t weird,” he said, commenting on approaching someone Highlight notifies you about.

For instance, knowing the person sitting next to you at a coffee shop is friends with your sister who lives across the country is cause to strike up a conversation.

Highlight points out the connections you have with the world around you, which Davison feels can make the world seem like a smaller place and connects people who might have otherwise never known each other.

SEE ALSO: Highlight Take Automatic Location-Based Sharing To The Next Level

Let's take a deeper dive in to some of the app's new features.

Post Nearby

A new Post Nearby feature allows you to send messages to those who you’re near at a particular time. When posted, Notes will be sent out as a push notification to the people around you using Highlight and will appear at the top of those individuals' activity feed.

Davison sees the feature as being used for things like asking for an iPhone charger from others at a coffee shop, or asking to share a cab home from a networking event. The possibilities are endless.

Posts can be responded to by others on Highlight, and when you move, your note will move along with you. For instance, if you’re on a business trip and ask the masses for bar recommendations while you’re at your hotel, the note will also show up when you decide to hit the bar a few blocks down the road, allowing you to potentially get better suggestions.

Improved Algorithm, Personalized Notifications, Interest Pages

In this release, Highlight has tweaked the algorithm that produces notifications on the service, which Davison says will create results that are more timely, personalized and interesting.

Highlight is also making the notifications you get a little more personal. Just like you might highlight a particular person you find interesting on the service, now you can also highlight particular interests that you care about. So, if you’d love to meet people who love the same bands you do, but could do without meeting people who also enjoy “hugging,” then you can let the app know.

New Interest Pages bring together all the people on Highlight who have a particular thing in common with you. For instance, if you’re at a party and want to know if anyone will support putting Lady Gaga on the stereo, you can tap "Lady Gaga" and instantly see who your allies in the room might be.

SEE ALSO: Highlight: Super-Hot. Now What?

Power users can now fine-tune what notifications they receive with more granular controls in the app’s settings.

Notes

Much like you can on LinkedIn, Highlight now allows you to leave notes on the profiles of people you know that will be visible to others who visit that person’s profile.

For instance, you might write a note on a friend’s page saying “Ask John to tell you what happened on his trip to Hawaii,” if John has a particularly interesting tale to tell. Or you might simply leave a note letting the world know how great John is.

You’ll need to be Facebook friends with a person in order to leave a note, and the note can be deleted by both the person who wrote it and the owner of the profile. That way if someone says something you don’t like, you can get rid of it.

Redesigned Activity Feed, Liking and Replying

The activity feed within Highlight has been redesigned in this release to incorporate the new types of content the app now supports. Notes about people you’ve crossed paths with, posts from people nearby, and information about people your friends have highlighted will all now show up in the activity feed.

From the feed you can now like and reply to posts. So, if you someone asks for an iPhone charger and you have one you can reply in-line from your Activity feed so everyone else can see.

Better Facebook Integration

Highlight has always gotten information about your mutual friends and interests from Facebook, and now the app lets you share to Facebook some information about what you do on Highlight.

Now when you highlight someone else, write a post, or write a note about someone, you can choose to share that information on your Facebook profile. You can also post a summary – along with pictures – of everyone you’ve encountered in a particular day. Everyone pictured will have to have also enabled the Facebook-sharing feature on their phones.

Language Support

Highlight is now available in French, Italian, German, Spanish, Dutch, Portuguese, Brazilian Portuguese, Chinese, Japanese and Korean.

You can download Highlight’s latest update now from the App Store.

Check out the gallery above for a look at some of the new features, and let us know what you think of the update in the comments.

Topics: Apps, Apps and Software, Highlight, iPhone, Mobile, Startups, Tech

title: Location-Sharing App Highlight Gets Biggest Update Since Launch
